results.title: Photography in science
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Photography: an introduction”.
Overviews the wide variety of applications for scientific photography from providing legal evidence to diagnosing diseases. It is used to document, measure, reveal and communicate. Advances in computer and digital technology are revolutionising scientific photography and some of these changes are explained.

results.title: Studio and Location
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Photography: an introduction”.
Profiles three Australian photographers - Jacqui Henshaw, Adrian Van Valen and John Gollings. Concentrating on fashion, architectural and car photography, they discuss the differences between shooting on location and in the studio with each context having its own advantages and limitations.

results.title: Photography around us
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Photography: an introduction”.
Offers an introduction to the history of photography in Australia and its gradual acceptance as an artform by museums and educational institutions. Local authorities in the field discuss changing attitudes to photography. In particular Sue Fereday, Director of the Centre for Contemporary Photography, and Isobel Crombie, Curator of Photography at the National Gallery of Victoria explain their policies towards collecting and exhibiting photography.

results.title: The Nuclear age
results.creator_credit: Julian Ware, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description: The Nuclear Age is a documentary series which provides a definitive account of the momentous events in the 40 year history of the nuclear arms race from the first atomic explosion to the signing of the INF Treaty.

results.title: Carter's new world
results.creator_credit: Austin Hoyt, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Nuclear age”.
Jimmy Carter began his presidency with a vision of a new world of non-nuclear peace, but his dream was shattered by constant domestic and international pressures. In 1977, when he took office, Carter pledged to reduce miltary spending, pursue a foreign policy based on human rights and to negotiate arms control with the Soviet Union. By 1981, he had ordered the Senate to halt the ratification of the SALT II Treaty and the deployment of MX and Cruise Missiles. This program examines the failure of Carter’s vision and includes frank interviews with the former President, his Secretary of State, Cyrus Vance, and Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei Gromyko.

results.title: At the brink
results.creator_credit: Peter Raymont, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Nuclear age”.
In an exclusive interview, former Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko speaks for the first time about his famous White House Meeting with President Kennedy at the height of the Cuban Missile Crisis, and refutes certain claims made at the time. “…Kennedy never raised the question of the presence of Soviet missiles in Cuba. I repeat, he never mentioned it.” The statesman recalled that the discussions were “full of sharp turns.” For the first time since the end of the Second World War, the Cuban Missile crisis brought the world to the brink of a Nuclear war.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Raymont, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)

results.title: The Weapon of choice
results.creator_credit: Sue Crowther, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Nuclear age”.
This program looks at the political, military and technological events that contributed to the Cold War between the Soviet Union and the United Statesof America. As tension rose between the two “Super-Powers’, the nuclear arms race began in earnest. When the Soviet Union exploded its first atomic bomb in 1949, President Truman stirred considerable controversy by deciding to pursue the development of the hydrogen bomb, six hundred times more powerful than the Hiroshima bomb. By 1953, the U.S. atomic arsenal had grown to over 1000 weapons.

results.title: Dawn
results.creator_credit: Alice Markowitz, David Espar, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Nuclear age”.
This program examines the background of the decision to drop the atomic bomb on Hiroshima on August 6, 1945. It was a decision which shocked and profoundly changed the world, killing and mutilating thousands. There were mixed reactions of pride and horror. “We had calculated beforehand how much destruction there would be. But seeing it on films was much more terrible.” was one reaction of the time. The pilot was given a hero’s welcome, a medal and a celebration party.

results.title: Spaceship Earth
results.creator_credit: Mike Kleinsteuber, John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Antelope Films and Network Television
results.brief_description: A series allowing the viewer to tour the earth with the aid of remote sensing technology. Combined with modern computing power, space technology is helping scientists to create a new global geography, in order to discover how our life support systems work and how natural and human forces change them.

results.title: The Watchkeepers
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Antelope Films and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
Satellite technology combined with computer graphics can present an enormous range of information about Spaceship Earth and its inhabitants. This information can be climatic, demographic, geographic, religious, horticultural, agricultural and social. This program reviews the range of information accessible via these combined technologies and with the help of the NASA computer examines the first “living portrait” of the earth.
